title: Why E-Discovery is a CIKM-Hard Problem

author: David Andreoff Evans, JustSystems Evans Research

segmentation: Frame this by.
Asking the question first about what E discovery is in second about why CI Cam should be interested, and so I'm really saying I'm really asking.
I'm really trying to describe why I think CIE discovery is the CI Cam hard.
Problem.
So you have all probably heard about the discovery, but very briefly it is the requirement to provide to a party in a lawsuit.
Documents that exist in electronic form electronic documents have wide scope.
This includes, especially email, but just about anything else that you can think of that would be held in electronic form and in any location, including on your thumb drives.
E Discovery today is supplementing what has been traditional discovery traditional discovery in legal cases.
Has involved large amounts, typically large amounts of paper documents, so E discovery is supplementing it today, but is gradually replacing the practice of working with paper documents.
But a critical observation is that most of the sensibilities about discovery in general are still rooted.
In the experience of people manually working with paper documents, that's one of the tensions that arises when trying to introduce technology into the community that.
Is concerned with Discovery Huawei.

Quarter of $1,000,000 for example.
There is a very high cost of failure.
The failure means failure in the sense of losing a case and that of course can amount to 10s of millions if not hundreds of millions of dollars, which is on the order of a small acquisition form.

There might be a few of those coming up.
So there are many, many kinds of cases that will involve.
E discovery and it will cost the parties involved a lot of money.
But what is CI Cam?
So historically?
Of course it's been one attempt in the ACM community to bring together those people who work in the areas of databases, information retrieval and knowledge management.
And while in the beginning that was a tighter, harder combination to to stimulate increasingly the three disciplines have come to share core methodologies.
And definitions of problems.
I think we see that.
Today, so typical CIKM 2008 problems include such things as data and text mining, aspects of knowledge discovery, semi automatic, structuring of information, social graphs, interactions.

Critically, though, the solutions involve combinations of technology often applied in critical sequences that exploit techniques from the three disciplines, and in many cases the success or failure doesn't depend so much on the algorithm as on the data structures that are chosen or the representation of features, and that's an important fact.
Audi discovery as well.
Now I've used the term CI Cam heart an I mean to contrast that with what we've often called AI hard problems.
Now AI hard problems are really hard in general they require the equivalents of near perfect, perfect human intelligence, probably more perfect than any human intelligence that we embody physically.
For example, the ability to automate scientific discovery.
This encompases perceptions, symbolic abstraction, reasoning.
Developing arguments and explanations all communicated and extended discourse.
We'd love to be able to do that fully, automatically, but we're not going to do that fully automatically for awhile.
See, Icam hard is hard, but it's not so hard that we can't imagine solutions.
So this is my informal characterization.
For example, we can imagine delivering to a user precisely the information the user requires in a particular context of work, or during some activity.
We can imagine it we can't do it today arbitrarily, but we can imagine it.
Now, challenges in E Discovery come in many forms.
Some of them are surprising to begin with.
The discovery involves lots of data.
Order of terabytes.
Much of the data has little actual value.
There is also typically some time constraint on the amount of time people have to work with the data.

This can vary a lot, but for example one might see anything from a month to six months of time associated with the discovery process, and often the analytical part of that process is compressed to a fraction of that time.
A lot more time is given to the companies in compliance, going out, finding the data, putting it down on disks, and turning it over.
Then on the analysis side.
Now the other feature of the discovery is that manual review is not gone.

So whatever you do, whatever solution you come up with, you can be sure there will be some human looking over the shoulder of the machine and actually touching paper or some version of the information.
To confirm the quality or the content.
A problem with this kind of data set is often redundancy, near redundancy info, redundancy, alot of things that look like they're absolutely redundant or not.
They are comments in one or two.
Sentence is on what is otherwise a large email.
It's the comment that makes all the difference by the kinds of techniques we've developed to deal with web pages.
We would see those as near redundant copies of, say, email messages, but they're not actually, and that presents a problem.
There's also the problem of embeddings encodings, and just generally the context or Co. Mingling and Co.
Occurrence of data.
I'll illustrate this a little bit more in a moment.
Another difference or feature is that the goals of processing.
Something that you might be assigned to do if you were given a task to assist in E discovery would be to enumerate our individuate.
All of the items in the electronic storage.
Oh, that's not as it turns out, easy at all.
It's an extraordinarily difficult problem.
You might be required to segregate from the storage the privileged material that can be legally withheld from the other party from the non privileged material well, what's privileged.
There's no classification set, no training set for privileged documents.
It's dependent upon the status of individuals and relationships to each other, how they've communicated with each other, how the information has subsequently been protected.
And whether or not this context justifies the particular context of some communication can be argued to to retain privilege.
Often one of the goals is to identify individuals and maybe a little material that should be involved in depositions.
So rather than look for items of information, one is often browsing the information in order to find.
Those people that you want to take into a room and beat into submission.
Use that term very metaphorically, of course.
We're not.
We're not doing anything for the vice president's office here.
There's the matter of establishing chains of custody and possession of knowledge are events at points in time, but those are the typical problems that want us.
Trying to solve.

So some of the framing issues that differ from what we see in CI Cam today, for example, is an emphasis on recall avoiding false negatives, ensuring exhaustive coverage, working with the human in the loop.
We often do find that humans can contribute provided we put them in little boxes and don't let them do too much on their own to assist are very powerful algorithms.
In this case, it's the other way around.
We really have to think of the human as the driving force.
There's an absence of reference or training data.
You simply have nothing presidential that you can use when going into these kinds of cases, and there's an absence of standard practice, so your good result may not be a good result to someone else.
It depends on the argument.
There's an extreme importance in context.
In particular, in the sense of a social network or social communications.
Time features when something happened is critical.
The replication of information may determine whether it's continued to be under an umbrella of protection or whether it's been made public.
Status of the people who are doing communications, the status of knowledge before after events.
These kinds of contextual features dominate some of the important questions.
And there's heterogeneous information typology.
We seen text, but we also see a great deal of non textual information.
Think of for example CAD files or photographs.
Those can be critical.
They contain evidence potentially.
How do you process that alongside the text?
There is a problem with multiple languages now.
I thought that would just be merely the problem of dealing with Chinese, Korean, Japanese, English and all the European languages.
It turns out to be the code as well.

When you go back into archives 10 and 15 years, you find code that hasn't been seen for 10 or 15 years and it needs to be managed in some fashion, if only to correctly identify the proper file types and.
That turns out to be actually a tricky problem, and there's an emphasis on non textual information.
Now some other distinctions from CI Cam practice include an emphasis on compliance.

I mean the focus here when a team is trying to do discovery is to comply with the requirements of an order a court's order, but it also is important to find or use information in a way that supports argumentation.
There is a forensic purpose.
Information should be developed that fits a narrative and you can imagine the narrative on one side of the table is different from the one on the other.

There's an emphasis on evidence information, whose interpretation is determined by circumstances where it's discovered this may contrast with, and it may be necessary to develop contrastive sets of information that do not support a particular hypothesis.
And there's ultimately, and this is the one.
Certainly one edge of the CI Cam hard side of this and emphasis on explanation.
Think of the progress we've made in QA, especially in factual QA, who what, when, where kinds of questions?
We have tried to deal with more complex kinds of questions, developing lists.

Looking at an array of information that may not all represent the single answer to a question, but explanations are what we need and it's very difficult to understand how to configure our systems today to retrieve information and organize it so that it creates a discourse that is an explanation.
Naturally, we'd have to have a theory of explanation.

But this particular case involved.

The number of files was about 1,000,000.

Well, it turns out there were a lot of non textual files that were important in this case, and they were big.
This set had many attachments.

People were happy to send around emails that were six and seven generations deep, all the attachments having been preserved through every iteration, and the attachments were some of those bigger electronic files.
There were also compressed archives.
After awhile they got to be too big, so they were sending around compressed archives and archives that were compressed inside compressed archives, and it was turtles all the way down.
There were multiple languages in evidence, many different kinds of message formats.
In the end, we found a rate of redundancy and duplication of about 50%.
It took about 2 1/2 days to figure out there was that much redundancy and there was a rate in the errors of the set we received that had already been individu.
Atede are itemized of about 10 percent.
10% of the material had been had, failed to have been properly itemized in catalog.

Let me give you an idea of something of what the process looks like Now this is very schematic and you know your experiences may vary, but in general after the scope of the discovery is defined, there is the process of gathering the data, enumerating items and removing the stuff.
You can remove and then delivering the data over.
In the meantime, there's a great deal of analysis and processing and review that goes on iteratively and.

We ended up doing a lexical Atom discovery because this was a very special domain in which common English words actually worked in combinations to create special concepts.
We did an LP analysis to identify.
And noun phrases in particular, but also some dependency relations.

We ended up doing term equivalence classes because there were many alphanumerics that were being used as synonyms of other common phrases, and they turned out to be important to collapse that class, we did a person identification.

Social network analysis.
